titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kenneth Scott Latourette Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Lynn Buckley Aber and Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 22:02

did.abstract: The papers contain extensive documentation of Latourette's personal life, scholarly activities, and involvement in various organizations. Latourette was a professor of missions and Oriental history at Yale University. He held leadership positions in the American Baptist Convention and Foreign Mission Society, American Historical Association, Far Eastern Association, International Committee of Y.M.C.A.'s, Japan International Christian University Foundation, United Board for Christian Colleges in China, World Council of Churches, and Yale-China Association.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Kenneth Scott Latourette Papers (RG 3), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

chronitem.event: Born in Oregon City, Oregon, son of DeWitt Clinton and Rhoda (Scott) Latourette
Traveling secretary, Student Volunteer Movement for Foreign Missions
Faculty member, College of Yale in China, Changsha, China (forced to return for health reasons)
Prof. of history, Reed College, Portland, Oregon
Prof. of history, Denison University, Granville, Ohio
Prof. of missions and Oriental history
Received Order of Jade from Chinese government
Chairman, Department of Religion, Graduate School, Yale
Director of Graduate Studies, Department of Religion, Yale

list.item: Latourette held leadership positions in the following organizations:
American Baptist Convention and Foreign Mission Society
American Historical Association
Far Eastern Association
International Board, Y.M.C.A.
Japan International Christian University Foundation
United Board for Christian Colleges in China
World Council of Churches
Yale-in-China Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

item.ref: The papers are arranged in five series:

scopecontent.p: The papers contain extensive documentation of Latourette's personal life , scholarly activities, and involvement in various organizations. The material organized in 1974 is given minimal description in this register. The material added in 1983, has been processed according to current YDSL standards and is described in more detail.

The first series, Correspondence, is divided into three Sections: Family Correspondence, General Correspondence, and Postcards. The Family Correspondence section contains letters to and from Latourette's more immediate relations. There are various letters addressed to "Uncle Ken" in the General Correspondence section because of that term's common usage among Latourette's students. The General Correspondence documents the full range of Latourette's involvements. A list of prominent correspondents is contained in the first folder of this series. Two bound volumes of letters written to Latourette by his colleagues at the time of his retirement are located in the oversize box of Personal Items and Memorabilia, Series III.

Material added to Series I in 1983 includes letters and papers related to Latourette's involvement in various organizations and projects. Latourette was, for example, Chairman of the Committee on Research of the International Missionary Council and in that capacity sought to assemble every few years a list of unpublished studies on missions topics. The material filed under International Missionary Council in Series I includes letters to and/or from prominent individuals in the field of missions such as Henrik Kraemer, John R. Mott, Julius Richter, D. M. Schlunk, Bengt Sundkler, and A. L. Warnshuis. Correspondence and papers filed under the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America contain interesting material related to a statement by Latourette about the "Cairo Communique" of December 1943 and subsequent responses.

The second series, Diaries and Ledgers, contain five diaries from the years 1905 to 1916 and two ledgers from the years 1917 to 1921 and 1922 to 1924. Latourette's experiences as a faculty member of Yale-in-China, 1910-1912, are documented in the diaries.
Series III, Personal Items and Memorabilia, contains photographs, degrees,citations, artifacts, and biographical documentation.

Series IV, Writings, Addresses, Notes, contains articles, book reviews, pamphlets, and papers by Latourette, reviews of Latourette's works, material related to his family, and manuscripts. Series V contains similar material that was added to the papers in 1983.

list.item: I. Correspondence and Collected Material
II.Diaries and Ledgers
III. Personal Items and Memorabilia
IV. Writings, Addresses, Notes
V. Writings, Addresses, Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided as follows:

list.item: Family Correspondence: Most of the letters in this section were written or received by KSL but some were exchanged between other members of the family. Correspondence of Latourette family members is filed by its author's name. The few letters received from non-relations are filed according to recipient. The material within each folder is arranged chronologically. A variety of Latourette family material, including letters- dated 1861 to 1862 from Ezra Fisher and possibly his wife, and "Family History: A Sketch", written by KSL, are located at the end of this section.

General Correspondence: The letters are arranged alphabetically by author, except for the few letters written by KSL, which are filed according to recipient. The material of denominations, conventions and local churches is frequently located under more than one heading. For example, correspondence related to local Baptist churches may be filed under "Baptist" or under the name of the city in which the church is located. It should be noted that Correspondence lacking a surname is filed by Christian name. Letters signed "John," for example, are filed in a folder labelled "J" at the beginning of the "J" correspondence. IIllegible signatures, anonymous letters, cards and fragments are filed at the end of the section. A list of lengthy or prominent correspondents is in the first folder.
Postcards: The postcards are divided into two categories, those received by KSL and those received by his father. The postcards are arranged chronologically.
Correspondence added in 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The original sequence of writings, clippings, and notes is divided into the following subsections:

list.item: A. Articles by KSL: arranged alphabetically by title
B. Book reviews by KSL: arranged alphabetically according to author
C. Reviews of KSL's books: arranged chronologically
D. Clippings related to family and general matters: arranged chronologically
E. Articles, pamphlets, manuscripts by KSL: arranged chronologically
F. Papers by KSL: arranged chronologically
G. Notes for lectures, talks, and sermons: arranged topically

did.unittitle: Of works by Richardson - Wu, plus misc. review published in YDN
Notes for lectures, talks, and sermons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two subsections: Lengthy manuscripts, and Brief or incomplete manuscripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The writings addendum is divided into three subsections:

list.item: A. Addresses, interviews, notes
B. Manuscripts: arranged alphabetically by title with dates noted as available
C. Published writings: arranged chronologically
